common misconception ! hawaii be not in the center of
the ring of fire , and it formation be not
cause by the ring of fire . let 's break
down why : 1 . the ring of fire :
the ring of fire be a major area in the
basin of the pacific ocean where a large number of
earthquake and volcanic eruption occur . it 's characterize by
a nearly continuous series of oceanic trench , volcanic arc
, and volcanic belt and plate movement . it essentially
mark the edge of the pacific tectonic plate where it
's collide , slide under , or move past other
tectonic plate . 2 . hawaii 's location : hawaii
, on the other hand , be locate in the
middle of the pacific tectonic plate , thousand of mile
away from any plate boundary . 3 . what cause
hawaii : hawaii be cause by a hotspot . a
hotspot be an area deep within the earth 's mantle
where unusually hot magma rise to the surface . this
plume of hot material stay relatively stationary ( do n't
move much ) . the pacific plate be constantly move
over this stationary hotspot . a the plate move ,
the hotspot `` burn '' through the plate , create
volcano . each time a part of the plate move
over the hotspot , a new volcano form . a
the plate continue to move , the old volcano move
away from the hotspot , become volcanically inactive , and
gradually erode , form the chain of island and seamount
( underwater mountain ) we see stretch northwest from the
main hawaiian island . the young , most active volcano
( like those on the big island ) be currently
sit directly over the hotspot . so , in summary
: ring of fire : cause by the interaction of
earth 's tectonic plate at their boundary . hawaii :
cause by a stationary mantle hotspot that the pacific plate
move over . that 's a super good guess ,
but hawaii be actually a little bit different ! 1
. the `` ring of fire '' : imagine our
earth be like a giant , big , big puzzle
make of huge , flat piece that move super slowly
. the `` ring of fire '' be like all
the place where those puzzle piece be crash or rub
into each other around a big circle . when they
crash , they make lot of fire mountain ( volcano
) and shaky ground ( earthquake ) ! it 's
like the bumpy , cracky edge of the puzzle .
2 . where hawaii be : hawaii be actually sit
right in the middle of one of those big ,
flat puzzle piece , super far away from all the
crashing and bumping edge ! 3 . what make hawaii
? instead , hawaii be make by something call a
`` hot spot '' ! imagine a tiny , super
hot little `` fire pit '' deep , deep under
the earth . this fire pit stay in the same
spot , like a candle you put down . but
the big puzzle piece ( where hawaii be ) be
slowly , slowly slide over that hot fire pit ,
like a giant tray move over a candle . every
time the puzzle piece slide over the fire pit ,
the fire pit make a new fire mountain ( a
new island ! ) pop up from the ocean !
then the puzzle piece keep slide , and the old
island move away from the fire pit and stop make
fire , and a new island start to grow over
the fire pit . that 's why hawaii have so
many island in a line , like step stone !
so , hawaii be special because it 's make by
a secret , fiery spot under the middle of the
ocean , not by the big crashing edge of the
earth where the ring of fire be ! that 's
a common and understandable misconception , but it 's important
to clarify : hawaii be not in the center of
the ring of fire , and it formation be not
cause by the ring of fire . here 's why
: 1 . the ring of fire : the ring
of fire be a vast horseshoe-shaped zone around the rim
of the pacific ocean where the edge of several major
tectonic plate meet , collide , and slide past each
other . this intense geological activity ( subduction , divergence
, transform fault ) be responsible for the vast majority
of the world 's earthquake and volcanic eruption . it
mark the boundary of the pacific plate . 2 .
hawaii 's location : hawaii be locate thousand of mile
away from any tectonic plate boundary , right in the
middle of the pacific tectonic plate . it 's an
`` intraplate '' volcanic chain . 3 . what cause
hawaii ( the hotspot theory ) : hawaii 's existence
be due to a mantle hotspot . stationary plume :
deep within the earth 's mantle , there be a
relatively stationary plume of unusually hot magma rise towards the
surface . this be the `` hotspot . '' move
plate : the pacific tectonic plate be constantly and slowly
move over this stationary hotspot . volcano formation : a
a section of the pacific plate pass over the hotspot
, the rise magma punch through the plate , create
a volcano . island chain : a the plate continue
it movement , the newly form volcano move away from
the hotspot , become volcanically inactive , and eventually erodes
. meanwhile , a new volcano begin to form directly
over the hotspot . this continuous process create the long
chain of hawaiian island and underwater seamount ( guyot )
that stretch across the pacific . the big island of
hawaii , with it active volcano , be currently position
directly over the hotspot . so , to summarize :
the ring of fire be a result of plate tectonics
at plate boundary . hawaii be a result of a
stationary mantle hotspot that the pacific plate move over ,
create volcano in the middle of a tectonic plate .
the famous quote `` those who can not remember the
past be condemn to repeat it '' be say by
george santayana . he be a spanish-american philosopher , essayist
, poet , and novelist . the quote be find
in his work `` the life of reason , or
the phase of human progress '' ( 1905 ) ,
specifically in the `` reason in common sense '' volume
. okay , that very smart thing be say by
a grown-up name george santayana ( say : san-tuh-yah-nuh )
. what it mean for a 5-year-old be like this
: imagine you touch a super hot stove , and
it hurt your finger ! ouch ! `` remember the
past '' mean you remember that it hurt , and
you learn not to touch the hot stove again .
but if you `` can not remember the past ,
'' it mean you forget that it hurt . and
then you might `` repeat it '' ã¢ââ you might
touch the hot stove again and hurt your finger all
over ! so , the grown-up be say that if
we do n't remember the mistake people make a long
time ago , we might make the same mistake again
and again ! it 's important to learn from what
happen before so we can do good next time !
end of chat alright , let 's cut to the
chase . syntax be about form . semantics be about
mean . here 's the breakdown : # # #
syntax ( the rule of structure ) what it be
: the set of rule govern the structure , arrangement
, and formation of valid expression , statement , or
construct within a give system ( like a language ,
program language , or logical system ) . it 's
the grammar , the punctuation , the order of operation
. concern with : whether something be well-formed , grammatically
correct , or valid accord to the system 's rule
. it do n't care if it make sense ,
only if it follow the blueprint . key question :
`` be this construct correctly ? '' think of it
a : the grammar police . example : 1 .
human language : `` the dog chase the cat .
'' ( syntactically correct english sentence ) `` chase the
cat dog the . '' ( syntactically incorrect english sentence
ã¢ââ word order be wrong ) `` colorless green idea
sleep furiously . '' ( syntactically correct english sentence ,
even though it 's nonsensical ) 2 . programming language
( e.g. , python ) : ` if x >
0 : ` ( syntactically correct python conditional ) `
if > 0 x : ` ( syntactically incorrect python
ã¢ââ wrong order/structure ) ` print ( `` hello ,
world ! `` ) ` ( syntactically correct ) `
prnt ( `` hello , world ! `` ) `
( syntactically incorrect ã¢ââ typo in function name , compiler/interpreter
will flag it ) # # # semantics ( the
rule of mean ) what it be : the study
of the meaning , interpretation , or effect of well-formed
expression , statement , or construct . it 's what
the structure do , represent , or implies . concern
with : whether something be understandable , sensible , true
, false , or what action it perform . it
assume the syntax be already correct . key question :
`` what do this mean or do ? '' think
of it a : the meaning police . example :
1 . human language : `` the dog chase the
cat . '' ( syntactically correct , and semantically meaningful
ã¢ââ we understand the action ) `` colorless green idea
sleep furiously . '' ( syntactically correct , but semantically
meaningless or nonsensical ã¢ââ idea do n't have color ,
sleep , or fury ) `` the bachelor be marry
. '' ( syntactically correct , but semantically contradictory ã¢ââ
a bachelor be , by definition , unmarried ) 2
. programming language ( e.g. , python ) : `
x = 10 / 2 ` ( syntactically correct .
semantically : assign the value 5 to ` x `
. ) ` x = 10 / 0 ` (
syntactically correct . semantically : invalid or undefined operation ,
will cause a runtime error ã¢ââ `` division by zero
'' be a semantic error , not a syntactic one
. ) ` while true : pas ` ( syntactically
correct . semantically : create an infinite loop which might
be an intended behavior or an unintended logical error .
) # # # the crucial distinction you can have
perfect syntax with nonsensical or erroneous semantics . ( e.g.
, `` colorless green idea , '' or ` x
= 10 / 0 ` ) you can sometimes convey
correct semantics with incorrect syntax , though a machine would
reject it . ( e.g. , `` me go store
'' ã¢ââ you understand what i mean , but it
's grammatically wrong ) in short : syntax : be
the sentence/code form correctly ? semantics : do the sentence/code
make sense or do what it 's suppose to do
? one dictate the form ; the other dictate the
content 's meaning or effect . both be essential for
effective communication and computation . alright , let 's strip
away the fluff . phonetics be the physical , observable
study of speech sound . what it be : the
concrete reality of how human make , transmit , and
perceive sound . focus : articulatory phonetics : how sound
be produce by the vocal organ ( tongue position ,
lip rounding , airflow , etc. ) . acoustic phonetics
: the physical property of sound wave ( frequency ,
amplitude , duration ) . auditory phonetics : how the
ear and brain process these sound . perspective : universal
. a [ p ] sound be a [ p
] sound , physically , regardless of the language it
's use in . it 's about what be say
. tool : spectrograph , mri scan , direct observation
of articulator . phonology be the abstract , functional study
of how sound be organize and use within a specific
language system to convey meaning . what it be :
the mental system of sound ; the rule and pattern
that govern how sound behave in a give language .
focus : phoneme : the small unit of sound that
can change the meaning of a word in a particular
language ( e.g. , /p/ vs. /b/ in english :
`` pat '' vs. `` bat '' ) . allophone
: variation of a single phoneme that do n't change
meaning ( e.g. , the `` p '' in ``
pat '' be aspirate [ pãâ° ] , while the
`` p '' in `` spat '' be unaspirated [
p ] ; these be phonetically different but phonologically the
same /p/ in english ) . phonotactics : the rule
govern permissible sound sequence in a language ( e.g. ,
`` str '' be allow in english , but ``
tl '' be n't at the beginning of a word
) . prosody : the pattern of stress , intonation
, and rhythm in a language . perspective : language-specific
. what 's a meaningful distinction in one language might
not be in another . it 's about how and
why sound work in a particular language . tool :
minimal pair , structural analysis , native speaker intuition .
the blunt difference : phonetics = the `` what ''
and `` how '' of make and hear sound .
it 's about the raw physical speech event . phonology
= the `` why '' and `` how '' of
sound function within a language system to create meaning .
it 's about the mental structure and rule . you
can do phonetics without reference to any specific language 's
meaning , just the sounds themselves . you ca n't
do phonology without understand how a specific language use those
sound to distinguish word and convey information . think of
it this way : phonetics be like study the individual
brick , their material , size , and how they
're physically make . phonology be like study the architectural
blueprint for a house , how those brick be organize
and combine accord to specific rule to form a functional
structure that serve a purpose . it 's impossible to
give a single , universally agreed-upon `` body count ''
because of the inherent complexity of war , the differ
methodology of casualty estimation , and the challenge of attribute
indirect death . however , we can look at estimate
from various credible source for major conflict and intervention since
the end of the vietnam war ( 1975 ) .
the term `` united state empire '' itself frame this
inquiry from a critical perspective , imply responsibility for a
wide range of outcome , not just direct combat death
. hereã¢ââs a breakdown , focus on both direct violence
and , where possible , indirect death , acknowledge that
these be often conservative estimate : key conflict and intervention
( post-1975 ) and estimate casualty : 1 . central
america ( 1980s - covert wars/proxy support ) : nicaragua
, el salvador , guatemala : u support for various
regime and insurgent group ( contra ) lead to widespread
conflict . estimate death directly attributable to u action or
proxy be difficult , but the overall death toll in
these civil war be immense . el salvador : ~75,000
death ( 1979-1992 ) . guatemala : ~200,000 death (
1960-1996 ) , with significant u support for regime implicate
in mass atrocity . nicaragua : ~30,000-50,000 death ( contra
war ) . attribution : while not all death be
directly from u troop , u training , funding ,
and arm of combatant significantly prolong and intensified these conflict
. 2 . invasion of grenada ( 1983 ) :
direct death : ~19 u , ~45 grenadian , ~25
cuban . ( small scale ) 3 . invasion of
panama ( 1989 ) : direct death : official u
figure claim ~500 panamanian military and civilian death . human
right group and independent investigation estimate significantly high , possibly
1,000-4,000 civilian death . 4 . first gulf war (
1990-1991 ) & sanction regime : direct combat ( iraq
) : estimate range widely , from 25,000 to 100,000
iraqi soldier kill directly by coalition force . civilian death
be likely in the low thousand during the conflict .
post-war sanction ( 1990s ) : this be where indirect
death become catastrophic . the un security council sanction ,
heavily enforce by the u , lead to the collapse
of iraqi infrastructure , healthcare , and food supply .
unicef and other organization estimate that hundred of thousand of
iraqi child ( some estimate go as high a 500,000
) die due to malnutrition , disease , and lack
of medicine directly link to the sanction . this period
be a prime example of indirect `` body count .
'' 5 . balkan intervention ( bosnia 1995 , kosovo
1999 ) : bosnia : nato airstrikes ( u heavily
involve ) contribute to end the war . the overall
war death toll be ~100,000 . u direct killing of
civilian be minimal , but the intervention influence the outcome
of a highly lethal conflict . kosovo : nato bombing
campaign ( us-led ) . estimate for yugoslav military and
serb civilian death from nato action range from 500 to
1,500 . 6 . war in afghanistan ( 2001-2021 )
: the cost of war project at brown university estimate
: afghan security force & civilian : approximately 176,000 death
from direct violence . taliban & other opposition fighter :
approximately 84,000 death . u military : ~2,400 . indirect
death : the cost of war project also emphasize that
`` indirect death '' from disease , lack of access
to food , water , and infrastructure damage likely significantly
outnumber direct violence death . these could push the total
well into the hundred of thousand more . 7 .
iraq war ( 2003-2011 ) & subsequent conflict against isi
: iraq body count ( ibc ) : document 186,000
ã¢ââ 210,000 civilian death from direct violence from 2003-2023 .
this be consider a conservative figure , base primarily on
medium report . the lancet study ( 2006 ) :
estimate 655,000 excess death between 2003-2006 , primarily due to
violence but also include indirect factor like breakdown of infrastructure
. this study be controversial but highlight the potential scale
. cost of war project : estimate 282,000 ã¢ââ 315,000
direct violence death in iraq ( civilian , military ,
police , insurgent ) since 2003 . indirect death :
similar to afghanistan , the breakdown of society , healthcare
, and infrastructure post-2003 have lead to potentially hundred of
thousand more indirect death that be hard to quantify but
directly result from the war 's condition . 8 .
drone strike & covert operation ( pakistan , yemen ,
somalia , libya , syria ) : since 9/11 ,
the u have conduct extensive drone campaign . bureau of
investigative journalism : estimate for pakistan , yemen , and
somalia civilian death from u drone strike range from ~900
to 2,000+ . total death ( include combatant ) be
high . libya ( 2011 ) : u participation in
nato intervention . civilian death from nato strike be relatively
low ( dozen to a few hundred ) , but
the intervention contribute to the country 's destabilization and subsequent
civil war , which have kill ten of thousand .
syria ( since 2014 ) : us-led coalition airstrikes against
isi have cause thousand of civilian death . airwars.org estimate
8,000-14,000+ civilian death from coalition action , with the u
be the primary actor . 9 . support for saudi-led
coalition in yemen ( since 2015 ) : the u
have provide crucial logistical , intelligence , and weapon support
to the saudi-led coalition in yemen . direct violence :
the conflict have directly kill ten of thousand of civilian
. indirect death : the un and other humanitarian group
estimate hundred of thousand of death ( possibly over 377,000
by the end of 2021 ) from starvation , disease
( cholera ) , and lack of healthcare ã¢ââ consequence
of the war and blockade that u support help sustain
. summary of `` body count '' : when you
add up these estimate , especially consider the broad definition
imply by `` united state empire '' and `` do
n't sugarcoat it '' ( which necessitate include indirect death
and death cause by proxy force or sustain conflict )
, the number become staggering : direct death from u
action/proxies : conservatively , the figure for direct violent death
in afghanistan , iraq , panama , syria , yemen
, and proxy war in central america easily push into
the hundred of thousand , likely exceed 1 million .
indirect death : when factor in the indirect death from
sanction ( iraq 1990s ) , post-war societal collapse ,
disease , malnutrition , and destroyed infrastructure in conflict like
iraq , afghanistan , and yemen , the total number
of human life lose in conflict where the u play
a significant , leading , or enable role likely run
into several million ( 2-5 million+ ) . it 's
crucial to understand that these number be not precise and
be subject to ongoing debate and research . no single
government agency or international body maintain a comprehensive count of
all life lose due to u foreign policy or military
action . however , the grim reality , even with
conservative estimate , be that the human cost of u
intervention and sustain conflict since the end of the vietnam
war be immense and profoundly devastate . alright , let
's strip away the nicety and look at how psycholinguistics
, in it cold , empirical gaze , reveal some
rather unflattering truth about the human condition . here be
aspect that reflect most negatively on humanity , without sugarcoat
: 1 . our deep susceptibility to linguistic manipulation and
cognitive bias : framing effect : psycholinguistics demonstrate how merely
how information be phrase , rather than it objective content
, profoundly influence our judgment and decision . we can
be sway by rhetorical trick , euphemism , or emotional
language to accept conclusion or take action that be not
in our rational self-interest . this mean we 're easily
dupe and less rational than we believe . anchor and
priming : the first piece of information we encounter (
the `` anchor '' ) or even subtly relate linguistic
cue ( `` prime '' ) can disproportionately influence subsequent
judgment . this reveal that our thinking be n't purely
logical ; it 's often a slave to initial ,
sometimes irrelevant , linguistic stimulus . we 're not a
independent in our thought a we 'd like to imagine
. confirmation bias ( linguistically reinforce ) : we preferentially
attend to , interpret , and recall information that confirm
our exist belief . psycholinguistics show how language can be
use to construct narrative that fee this bias , make
u incredibly resistant to contradictory evidence , especially when that
evidence be present in a way that challenge our establish
linguistic framework . this highlight our inherent tribalism and intellectual
laziness . 2 . the pervasive use of language for
deception and obfuscation : euphemism and doublespeak : our capacity
to create and utilize language allow u to invent term
that obscure harsh reality , make terrible action sound palatable
, and sanitize brutality . think of `` collateral damage
'' instead of `` dead civilian , '' or ``
enhanced interrogation technique '' instead of `` torture . ''
psycholinguistics observe how effectively these linguistic construct bypass our moral
alarm system and allow u to justify or ignore horrific
act . this expose a deep human willingness to deceive
ourselves and others for convenience , power , or to
avoid guilt . strategic ambiguity : we often use language
that be deliberately vague or open to multiple interpretation to
avoid commitment , deflect blame , or maintain plausible deniability
. this be n't just a communication quirk ; it
's a tool for political maneuvering , corporate spin ,
and personal evasion , reveal a calculating , self-serving aspect
of our nature . 3 . language 's role in
reinforce prejudice and stereotype : categorization and labeling : our
brain naturally categorize the world through language . however ,
psycholinguistics show how these linguistic category can quickly ossify into
rigid stereotype . the label we apply to group (
`` them , '' `` foreigner , '' `` illegals
'' ) activate associate negative semantic network , make it
easy to dehumanize , discriminate against , and act violently
towards others . this reflect our inherent tribalism and our
tendency to use language a a weapon of exclusion .
implicit bias in language : subtle linguistic choice ( e.g.
, gendered language , passive voice to obscure agency )
can perpetuate unconscious bias . we absorb these pattern from
our linguistic environment , and they shape our perception and
action without our conscious awareness . this demonstrate how deeply
ingrained and insidious prejudice can be , operate below the
level of conscious intent . 4 . the critical period
and the fragility of our humanity : the concept of
a `` critical period '' for language acquisition , while
perhaps not absolute , highlight our profound vulnerability . if
a child be deprive of linguistic input during crucial developmental
window , their ability to acquire full , functional language
be severely impaired , often permanently . this be n't
just a biological limitation ; it tragically underscore how utterly
dependent we be on social interaction for our very definition
of `` humanity . '' the case of feral child
or those subject to extreme neglect demonstrate that without language
, the `` human '' mind struggle to fully develop
in key cognitive and social way . it expose our
deep social dependence and the horrific consequence when humanity fail
it most vulnerable member . 5 . our cognitive laziness
and tendency towards superficial processing : psycholinguistics reveals that our
brain be incredibly efficient but also cognitively `` lazy .
'' we often engage in superficial processing of language ,
pick up just enough mean to get by rather than
deeply analyze every word or inference . this efficiency allow
for rapid communication but also make u prone to misunderstand
, accept glib explanation , and fail to question information
critically . it show a human tendency to conserve mental
effort , even at the cost of accuracy or deep
insight . in essence , psycholinguistics lay bare how our
most defining trait ã¢ââ language ã¢ââ be a double-edged sword
. while it enable incredible feat of cooperation and expression
, it also expose our deep-seated irrationality , our capacity
for deception , our susceptibility to manipulation , our propensity
for prejudice , and our fundamental vulnerability . it show
u not a purely rational , objective being , but
a creature whose thought and action be profoundly shaped and
often limit by the very linguistic tool we wield .
alright , let 's strip away the fluff . bake
a truly delicious cake be n't magic ; it 's
science , precision , and respect for ingredient and process
. if you want a consistently amazing cake , here
's the no-nonsense approach : 1 . the recipe be
your blueprint . do n't wing it . find a
proven winner : do n't start with some obscure blog
or aunt mildred 's vague scribble . look for recipe
from reputable source : establish cookbook , highly-rated food website
( serious eats , king arthur baking , bon appãâ©tit
, atk ) . they 've test these thing rigorously
. read it . all of it . twice .
before you even touch an ingredient , read the entire
recipe . understand the step , foresee any challenge ,
and make sure you have everything . this be n't
optional . 2 . ingredient : quality , temperature ,
and precision . quality matter . a lot . you
ca n't make a silk purse out of a sow
's ear . use good quality butter ( unsalted ,
82 % + fat if possible ) , fresh egg
, good vanilla , and fresh leavening agent ( bake
soda/powder ã¢ââ check expiration date ) . shitty ingredient make
a shitty cake . temperature be non-negotiable : room temperature
butter/eggs/milk : this be the single most important temperature rule
. butter need to be soft enough to cream properly
( indent slightly when press , but not greasy or
melt ) . cold ingredient do n't emulsify properly with
cream butter and sugar , lead to a curdled batter
, which mean a dense , crumbly cake . plan
ahead . hot liquid ( if call for ) :
if a recipe say hot coffee or boiling water ,
it mean hot or boil . it activate cocoa powder
and bake soda differently than cold liquid . precision :
get a kitchen scale . period . measure flour by
volume ( cup ) be wildly inaccurate due to compaction
. 1 cup of flour can vary by up to
20-30 gram . a kitchen scale provide consistent result every
single time . for everything else ( sugar , liquid
) , level your cups/spoons properly . 3 . equipment
: you need the right tool . oven thermometer :
your oven 's internal thermostat be probably lie to you
. buy a cheap oven thermometer and stick it in
there . adjust your oven dial to match the actual
temperature you need . this be crucial for consistent baking
. good quality pan : light-colored , heavy-gauge aluminum pan
conduct heat more evenly than dark pan ( which can
lead to burn edge and undercooked center ) or flimsy
one . make sure they be the exact size the
recipe call for . parchment paper : liner for cake
pan be a godsend . no sticking , easy release
. cut circle for the bottom , and grease the
side . 4 . preparation : mise en place (
everything in it place ) . preheat your oven properly
: give it at least 20-30 minute after it signal
it 's preheat to reach and stabilize the correct temperature
. use your oven thermometer to verify . prep your
pan : grease and flour them , or grease and
line with parchment . do n't do this while the
batter be wait ã¢ââ do it first . measure everything
: get all your ingredient measure out and ready before
you start mix . this prevent frantic searching or accidental
omission . 5 . mix method : follow instruction to
the letter ( and understand why ) . cream method
( butter cake ) : cream butter and sugar thoroughly
until light and fluffy . this incorporate air , which
be critical for lift and tenderness . add eggs one
at a time , mix well after each . then
alternate dry and wet ingredient . do n't overmix after
flour be add : once flour hit liquid , gluten
development begin . overmixing develop too much gluten , make
your cake tough and chewy . mix until just combine
ã¢ââ streak of flour be okay , they 'll disappear
in the oven . scrape down the bowl : frequently
scrape down the side and bottom of your mix bowl
to ensure all ingredient be evenly incorporate . 6 .
baking : patience and observation . do n't open the
oven door : especially in the first two-thirds of baking
time . it drop the temperature and can cause your
cake to collapse . center rack : bake cake on
the center rack for even heat distribution . test for
doneness , do n't just trust the timer : timer
be a guide . cake be do when : a
wooden skewer or toothpick insert into the center come out
clean or with a few moist crumb ( no wet
batter ) . the edge pull slightly away from the
pan . the top spring back lightly when gently press
. the internal temperature reach 200-210ãâ°f ( 93-99ãâ°c ) .
7 . cooling : do n't rush this step .
in the pan : let the cake cool in it
pan on a wire rack for 10-15 minute . this
allow the cake 's structure to set without tear when
invert . on the rack : invert cake onto a
wire rack and let them cool completely to room temperature
. frost a warm cake be for amateur ; it
will melt your frost into a sugary mess . 8
. frost & decoration : cake must be cold :
seriously . crumb coat : apply a thin layer of
frosting , chill until firm , then apply the final
, thicker coat . this traps crumb and give you
a smooth finish . the unsugarcoated truth : your first
cake wo n't be perfect : get over it .
baking be a skill , and skill require practice .
be patient : rush any step will compromise the final
product . learn from your mistake : if a cake
fail , try to understand why . be the butter
too cold ? do you overmix ? do the oven
lie ? do n't improvise until you understand the science
: changing ratio , ingredient , or temperature without understand
their impact be a recipe for disaster . bake a
truly delicious cake be a mastery of fundamental . follow
the rule , pay attention to detail , and use
good ingredient . there 's no secret ingredient beyond that
. alright , buckle up . linguistics be in a
fascinating , sometimes turbulent , and incredibly fast-moving period ,
largely due to one massive disruptor . here be the
most recent development , raw and unfiltered : # #
# the ai/computational linguistics revolution ( the elephant in the
room ) this be by far the most significant development
, impact every other subfield . 1 . large language
model ( llm ) and generative ai : the dominant
force : the advent of transformer architecture ( like gpt-3/4
, bert , llama ) have completely reshape computational linguistics
and be send ripple through theoretical linguistics . these model
can generate human-quality text , translate , summarize , and
even `` reason '' in way that challenge previous assumption
about language intelligence . new research paradigm : much of
nlp research now revolve around fine-tuning , prompting , and
evaluate these gargantuan model . this have lead to the
rise of `` prompt engineering '' a a skill .
multilingual breakthrough : llm , especially highly multilingual one ,
be achieve unprecedented performance in low-resource language , potentially democratize
access to language technology . the `` black box ''
problem : while incredibly powerful , llm be largely opaque
. understand how they achieve their linguistic feat remain a
massive research area , prompt new method for interpretability and
explainability . ethical minefield : bias ( gender , race
, socio-economic ) , hallucination ( make up fact )
, misuse ( disinformation , deepfakes ) , job displacement
, intellectual property right , and environmental impact ( compute
power ) be massive , ongoing concern . these be
n't just technical problem ; they 're deeply linguistic and
societal . 2 . computational social science & digital humanity
: big data for sociolinguistics : researcher be use computational
tool to analyze vast datasets from social medium , forum
, and digitize historical text to track language change ,
identify linguistic community , and study the spread of linguistic
innovation in real-time . network analysis : mapping how language
feature spread through social network . discourse analysis at scale
: automate method for identify sentiment , frame , and
rhetorical strategy in massive text corpus . # # #
cognitive & neuro-linguistics 3 . refine neuroimaging technique & brain-computer
interface ( bci ) : deep insight into processing :
fmri , eeg , meg , and intracranial recording be
provide increasingly precise temporal and spatial resolution on how the
brain process language . this include study on sentence comprehension
, word recognition , and bilingualism . language production mapping
: advanced technique be help map the neural pathway involve
in speech planning and execution , and even decode ``
inner speech '' with bcis . embody cognition : grow
evidence support theory that language processing be deeply intertwine with
sensory and motor system , rather than be a purely
abstract module . how we understand `` kick '' involve
activate motor region , for example . 4 . usage-based
& constructivist approach gain ground : challenging nativism : while
chomskyan generative grammar still hold sway in some theoretical circle
, usage-based model ( e.g. , construction grammar , cognitive
linguistics ) be increasingly influential , particularly in psycholinguistics and
language acquisition research . these model emphasize that linguistic structure
emerge from repeat exposure to language use , rather than
innate , pre-specified rule . learn from data : the
success of data-driven llm inadvertently lend support to usage-based perspective
, show how complex linguistic pattern can emerge from vast
amount of experience . # # # sociolinguistics & language
variation/change 5 . language and identity in the digital age
: online identity construction : how people use language to
construct and perform identity ( gender , sexuality , race
, political affiliation ) in online space . this include
emojis , slang , unique orthography , and specific discourse
practice . intersectionality : increased focus on how various social
category intersect to shape linguistic practice and perception . language
activism & ideology : the role of language in social
justice movement , debate around `` inclusive language , ''
and the often-heated discussion about language ideology online . 6
. continue work on language endangerment & revitalization : digital
tool for revitalization : linguist be collaborate with community to
use digital platform ( apps , online dictionary , social
medium ) to document , teach , and promote endanger
language . decolonize linguistics : a grow critical perspective challenge
traditional western academic approach to language documentation and shifts power
to speaker community . # # # theoretical linguistics (
the internal debate intensify ) 7 . the llm challenge
to generative grammar : fundamental question : do llm learn
abstract , hierarchical syntactic structure ( a generative grammar posit
) , or do they primarily learn statistical dependency and
surface pattern ? this be a hot-button issue . new
`` test '' for theory : researcher be design experiment
use llm to probe their internal representation , try to
see if they mimic human syntactic processing . the jury
be out , and the debate be fierce . some
see llm a a vindication of statistical learning , others
a demonstrate a need for more robust theoretical understanding that
llms do n't yet possess . minimalism continue to evolve
: within generative grammar , the minimalist program continue to
explore the `` simple '' possible computational system for language
, often focus on cross-linguistic generalization . 8 . formal
semantics & pragmatic intersect with cognitive model : meaning in
context : attempt to bridge the gap between abstract logical
representation of meaning and how meaning be construct and negotiate
in real-world communicative context , often draw on insight from
cognitive science . computational semantics : incorporate llm representation into
formal semantic theory . # # # overarch trend &
challenge radical interdisciplinarity : linguistics be increasingly a hub discipline
, collaborate intensely with computer science , psychology , neuroscience
, anthropology , biology ( for language evolution ) ,
and sociology . data-driven vs. theory-driven : the sheer volume
of linguistic data now available ( and the power of
ai to process it ) sometimes overshadow theoretical development .
there 's a tension between `` what the data say
'' and `` what our theory predict/explain . '' the
funding skew : a significant portion of funding and attention
be shift towards ai/nlp , potentially leave other crucial area
of linguistic inquiry under-resourced . reproducibility & `` p-hacking ''
: like many science , linguistics ( especially experimental psycholinguistics
) face ongoing concern about research reproducibility and the proper
use of statistical method . define `` understanding '' and
`` knowledge '' : the spectacular performance of llms force
linguist and philosopher of language to re-examine what it mean
for a system ( or a human ) to ``
understand '' or `` know '' a language , and
whether mere predictive accuracy equate to true linguistic competence .
in short , linguistics be currently dominate by the computational
wave , especially llms . this have create immense excitement
and new tool , but also profound theoretical challenge ,
ethical dilemma , and a scramble to understand what these
powerful system actually know about human language , and what
their rise mean for the future of the field itself
. alright , let 's strip away the fluff .
build a truly useful linguistic corpus , one that serve
a a robust foundation for serious research and advance nlp
, require these fundamental layer of annotation . anything less
and you 're leave significant analytical power on the table
. here be the most fundamental way a linguistic corpus
should be annotate , in rough order of necessity :
# # # 1 . metadata ( the absolute bedrock
) what it be : information about the text itself
, not it linguistic content . why it 's fundamental
: without this , your corpus be just a pile
of text . you ca n't filter , compare ,
generalize , or understand the context of the language .
source : where do this text come from ? (
e.g. , newspaper , novel , transcribe speech , social
medium , scientific paper ) date : when be it
produce ? ( crucial for track language change , topical
relevance ) author/speaker : who produce it ? ( demographic
: age , gender , dialect , socioeconomic status ã¢ââ
vital for sociolinguistics ) genre/domain : what kind of text
be it ? ( e.g. , news report , casual
conversation , legal document , poem ) language/dialect : obvious
, but essential to specify if work with multilingual corpus
or dialectal variation . mode : write , speak ,
multimodal ? licensing/copyright : practical but necessary for ethical use
. # # # 2 . tokenization & sentence segmentation
( the first step ) what it be : tokenization
: break down text into discrete `` token '' (
word , punctuation , number ) . sound trivial ,
but `` do n't , '' `` u.s.a. , ''
`` new york '' be complex . sentence segmentation :
dividing text into individual sentence . why it 's fundamental
: you ca n't do anything else reliably without know
where word and sentence begin and end . this be
the very first programmatic step in nearly all nlp task
. error here propagate everywhere else . # # #
3 . part-of-speech ( po ) tagging ( unlocking grammar
) what it be : assign a grammatical category (
e.g. , noun , verb , adjective , preposition ,
determiner ) to each token . why it 's fundamental
: basic syntactic understanding : it tell you what kind
of word each token be . disambiguation : `` read
'' a a verb vs. `` read '' a a
noun ( the book be a good read ) .
feature engineering : essential input for almost all higher-level nlp
task ( parse , name entity recognition , machine translation
) . lexical analysis : grouping word by their grammatical
function . # # # 4 . lemmatization ( normalize
lexical item ) what it be : reduce inflected form
of a word to it base or dictionary form (
lemma ) . `` run , '' `` running ,
'' `` run '' ã¢ââ `` run '' `` well
, '' `` best '' ã¢ââ `` good '' why
it 's fundamental : reduces data sparsity : allow you
to count unique lexical item regardless of inflection . improve
search/retrieval : searching for `` run '' find all it
form . crucial for lexical semantics : allow analysis of
word meaning independent of their grammatical realization . # #
# 5 . syntactic parsing ( understanding structure ) what
it be : analyze the grammatical structure of sentence .
this usually take two main form : constituency parse (
phrase structure ) : breaking sentence into hierarchical phrase (
noun phrase , verb phrase , prepositional phrase , etc.
) . represent a parse tree . dependency parsing :
identifying grammatical relationship ( dependency ) between word in a
sentence ( e.g. , subject , object , modifier )
. represent a directed graph . why it 's fundamental
: the gateway to understanding grammatical relation : who do
what to whom ? what modify what ? essential for
information extraction : finding relation between entity . machine translation
: understanding source sentence structure be key to generate target
sentence . semantic role labeling : often build on top
of parse . # # # 6 . name entity
recognition ( ner ) & classification ( real-world entity )
what it be : identifying and classify `` name entity
'' in text . person : `` john smith ''
organization : `` google inc. '' location : `` new
york city '' date/time : `` october 26th , 2023
'' money/percent : `` $ 500 , '' `` 20
% '' why it 's fundamental : information extraction :
extracting key piece of information from unstructured text . question
answering : answering question that involve specific entity . summarization
: identifying key player and place . data link :
connect entity in text to external knowledge base . #
# # 7 . coreference resolution ( track entity )
what it be : identifying expression that refer to the
same real-world entity . `` john say he would come
. he arrive late . '' ( john and the
first he refer to the same person . the second
he also refer to the same person . ) ``
the company announce it new product . it be expect
to be a market leader . '' why it 's
fundamental : discourse understanding : crucial for understand continuity and
track entity across sentence and paragraph . information extraction :
connect all mention of an entity . question answering :
understanding `` who '' or `` what '' a pronoun
refers to . summarization : help in building coherent summary
. # # # the brutal truth about annotation :
it 's expensive and time-consuming : manual annotation be slow
, laborious , and require highly skilled annotator ( especially
for parse or coreference ) . it 's the most
significant bottleneck in corpus development . language be ambiguous :
annotator will disagree . you must have clear , detailed
guideline and measure inter-annotator agreement ( iaa ) . low
iaa render your annotation unreliable . theoretical bias : annotation
scheme be not neutral ; they embed specific linguistic theory
and assumption . be transparent about them . scalability challenge
: manual annotation do n't scale well . you 'll
always be try to bootstrap large annotate corpus from small
, manually-annotated seed data use semi-supervised or weakly supervise method
. purpose-driven annotation : do n't just annotate everything because
you can . annotate what be genuinely necessary for your
research question or target application . over-annotating be a waste
of resource . if you do n't have these core
annotation , you 're severely limit the type of linguistic
analysis and nlp application you can derive from your corpus
. you 're effectively operate at a superficial level ,
miss out on the rich , structured information that truly
make a corpus powerful . end of chat okay ,
let 's do both ! first , the coin flip
: head ! a for chess , while i ca
n't set up a full , interactive game with a
board that track move like a dedicated chess program (
my interface be n't design for that level of complexity
) , we can definitely talk about chess ! how
about we : 1 . discuss an opening ? (
e.g. , `` what 's a good response to 1
. e4 ? '' ) 2 . analyze a specific
position ? ( you can describe it or give me
a fen string . ) 3 . solve a chess
puzzle ? ( i can describe one for you .
) 4 . just make some 'imaginary ' move ?
( you tell me your first move , and i
can tell you what i 'd play in response ,
without u try to track the whole game . )
what sound fun for our chess chat ? a an
ai , i do n't actually `` play '' chess
, so i do n't have a color or make
move myself in a live game . however , if
we 're talk about the first move for white in
a standard chess game , the most common and classic
opening move be e4 ( pawn to e4 ) .
okay , 1 ... e5 . this be a classic
and excellent response to 1. e4 . it stake a
claim in the center , open line for the queen
and bishop , and prevents white from play d4 immediately
. the most common and generally consider best response for
white be 2 . nf3 . this develop a knight
to a good square . it attack your e5 pawn
. it prepare for castle kingside . other good and
common option for white include : 2 . nc3 (
vienna game , or lead to four knight game )
2. f4 ( king 's gambit - a very aggressive
pawn sacrifice ) 2. d4 ( center game - also
involve a pawn sacrifice or trade ) what would you
like to play next ? `` nh6 '' in chess
notation mean that a knight move to the h6 square
. to give you more context or analyze the move
, i would need to know : whose turn it
be ( white or black ) the current state of
the chessboard ( all the piece and their position )
general electric ( ge ) be one of the most
iconic and historically significant corporation in american history , represent
the very essence of industrial innovation and diversified capitalism for
over a century . it journey from a pioneer electric
company to a sprawl global conglomerate , and then it
dramatic unraveling , offer a compelling business saga . #
# history of general electric corporation 1 . the genesis
: edison 's vision & merger ( late 19th century
) edison electric light company ( 1878 ) : thomas
edison 's company , found to commercialize his invention of
the practical incandescent light bulb , be the direct precursor
. thomson-houston electric company : another prominent electrical firm ,
equally innovative . the merger ( 1892 ) : j.p.
morgan orchestrate the merger of edison general electric company (
form from edison electric light and other edison venture )
with thomson-houston electric company to create the general electric company
. this instantly make ge a dominant force in the
nascent electricity industry . early innovation : ge quickly become
a leader in power generation , transmission , lighting ,
and industrial equipment . it schenectady , ny research laboratory
( establish 1900 ) be one of the first and
most important industrial research facility in the world , responsible
for countless breakthrough . 2 . mid-20th century : industrial
powerhouse & diversification ( 1920s-1970s ) consumer good : ge
diversify early into consumer appliance ( refrigerator , wash machine
, radio , tv ) , become a household name
. wartime production : a major contributor during world war
i and especially world war ii , produce everything from
jet engine to radar system , significantly expand it manufacturing
capability . broad industrial base : post-war , ge solidify
it position across a vast array of industry : jet
engine ( ge aviation ) , plastic ( ge plastic
) , medical imaging ( ge healthcare ) , nuclear
power , financial service , and more . it be
a true industrial behemoth . 3 . the jack welch
era : `` neutron jack '' and the conglomerate peak
( 1981-2001 ) radical transformation : ceo jack welch be
perhaps the most celebrated and controversial leader in ge 's
history . he aggressively restructure the company , famously decree
that ge must be # 1 or # 2 in
every market it operate in , or it would be
fix , sell , or close . growth and acquisition
: welch oversee immense growth through both organic expansion and
a relentless pace of acquisition . ge 's market capitalization
soar , make it , for a time , the
most valuable company in the world . six sigma :
he champion the six sigma quality management methodology , which
become a widely adopt industry standard . rise of ge
capital : crucially , welch significantly expand ge capital ,
the company 's financial service arm . this division grow
to be enormous , provide financing for aircraft , power
plant , real estate , consumer loan , and more
, eventually account for a significant portion ( sometimes over
50 % ) of ge 's profit . management guru
: welch become a corporate legend , his management principle
study and emulate globally . 4 . the post-welch decline
: immelt , flannery , and the unraveling ( 2001-2018
) jeff immelt ( 2001-2017 ) : welch 's successor
, immelt , face immediate challenge ( 9/11 , dot-com
bust ) and struggle to steer the massive conglomerate .
the financial crisis ( 2008 ) : this be a
pivotal moment . ge capital , highly leveraged and involve
in many risky market , face collapse and required government
backing , expose it vulnerability . this force a major
, painful divestment of many ge capital asset . poor
acquisition : immelt make several large , ill-fated acquisition (
e.g. , alstom 's power business ) that fail to
generate expect return and add to complexity . struggle industrial
core : while ge make effort to return to it
industrial root , many division struggle with profitability , innovation
, and execution . `` earnings smooth-out '' : accusation
arise of opaque accounting and a culture of `` manage
'' earnings to meet target , rather than reflect true
performance . john flannery ( 2017-2018 ) : bring in
to accelerate change , flannery announce radical restructuring plan and
dividend cut but be remove after only a year due
to the accelerate decline and stock price collapse . 5
. the larry culp era : deconstruction and rebirth (
2018-present ) first external ceo : larry culp , the
former ceo of danaher , be bring in a the
first outsider to lead ge . he embark on an
aggressive plan to simplify and de-leverage the company . historic
break-up : culp 's most significant decision be to break
ge into three independent , publicly trade company : ge
healthcare : spun off in january 2023 . ge vernova
: ( power , renewable energy , digital ) schedule
to spin off in early 2024 . ge aerospace :
the remain aviation business , which will retain the ge
name and legacy . this deconstruction mark the end of
the traditional ge conglomerate and a desperate bid for it
constituent part to thrive a focused entity . # #
the fall from esteem and grace : explanation ge 's
spectacular fall from grace can be attribute to a confluence
of strategic misstep , cultural issue , and external market
force : 1 . over-reliance on ge capital and financialization
: masking industrial weakness : ge capital 's consistent ,
albeit often opaque , profit during the welch era and
early immelt year mask underlying performance issue in the core
industrial business . it create an illusion of strength .
vulnerability to financial crisis : the 2008 financial crisis expose
ge capital 's excessive leverage and risky asset . it
become a liability that nearly bring down the entire company
, shake investor confidence to it core . cultural shift
: the pursuit of financial engineering over industrial innovation become
ingrained , divert talent and resource from manufacture prowess .
2 . excessive diversification and conglomerate discount : lack of
focus : ge 's vast array of business , from
jet engine to light bulb to mri machine to financial
service , become too unwieldy to manage effectively . no
single management team could master such disparate industry . ``
conglomerate discount '' : investor often penalize highly diversified company
, a it 's believe they ca n't manage all
segment optimally , and shareholder can diversify themselves more efficiently
. ge 's complexity make it difficult to value .
slow decision-making : the sprawl bureaucracy slow innovation and adaptation
in rapidly change market . 3 . poor leadership and
succession ( post-welch ) : immelt 's struggle : while
immelt inherit a challenging landscape , his tenure be mark
by a series of underperforming acquisition , failure to fully
address the ge capital problem until force , and a
perceived lack of transparency . lack of agility : the
leadership struggle to pivot the massive company fast enough to
new market reality , like the shift towards renewables or
digital technology . 4 . cultural issue and lack of
transparency : `` earnings smooth-out '' culture : under pressure
to meet aggressive financial target ( a welch legacy that
persist ) , there be a strong internal culture of
`` manage '' quarterly earnings , sometimes through questionable accounting
practice ( e.g. , book long-term service contract a immediate
revenue ) . this lead to accusation of fraud and
eventually massive write-down and sec investigation . bloat bureaucracy :
despite welch 's initial cut , the company remain highly
bureaucratic and resistant to change in late year . 5
. failure to adapt and innovate in core industry :
while ge be historically innovative , some of it core
industrial segment ( power generation , particularly gas turbine )
suffer from a lack of r & d investment relative
to competitor , lead to a loss of market share
and profitability . the shift to renewable energy caught ge
somewhat flat-footed , and it wind turbine business struggle .
6 . debt burden : a consequence of aggressive acquisition
and support ge capital , the company accumulate a massive
amount of debt , further cripple it ability to invest
and innovate . in essence , ge 's fall be
a cautionary tale of a once-unassailable industrial giant that grow
too big , too complex , and too reliant on
financial engineering , ultimately lose it innovative edge and market
trust . it current deconstruction be a desperate , yet
perhaps necessary , attempt to salvage value from it once-illustrious
name . end of chat damian lillard win the 2024
nba all-star three-point contest . northern elephant seal can hold
their breath for up to 100 minute . medea flees
athens in a dragon-drawn chariot , provide by her grandfather
helius , and go to the city of athens ,
where she be grant sanctuary by king aegeus ( a
pre-arranged earlier in the play ) . the prevail wind
in the tropic blow from east to west . these
be know a the trade wind . the brisket of

twin city '' because they grow into each other .
hyderabad be the old , large , and capital city

nizams . secunderabad be originally establish a a british cantonment
town in the early 19th century , adjacent to hyderabad
. essentially , secunderabad be a separate military and administrative
area set up by the british next to the native
state of hyderabad . today , they be functionally integrate
into one large metropolitan area , but secunderabad still retain
it distinct railway station and some historical character . the

the story of he never die center on jack (
play by henry rollins ) , a world-weary , immortal
, and deeply cynical man live a solitary , monotonous
existence in a rundown urban apartment . he 's curse
with eternal life and an insatiable need to consume human
flesh to sustain himself ( though he try to limit
it to blood from a doctor or small portion )
. his quiet routine of bingo , diner meal ,
and avoid human connection be shatter when his estrange teenage
daughter , andrea , suddenly appear on his doorstep .
simultaneously , element from his violent past resurface . a
local gangster , alex , who owe jack money ,
come look for him , and soon andrea become a
target , kidnap to force jack 's hand . reluctantly
, jack be force to abandon his self-imposed detachment and
unleash the brutal , superhuman violence he 's try to
suppress . throughout the film , it 's reveal that
jack be n't just immortal ; he be in fact
cain from the bible , curse by god to walk
the earth forever after murder his brother abel . this
explain his inability to die and his unique dietary requirement
. he carve a bloody path through anyone who threaten
andrea or get in his way , showcasing his instant
healing and invulnerability . the film be a dark ,
violent , and surprisingly comedic exploration of existential dread ,
familial responsibility , and the burden of eternal life .
by the end , andrea be safe , but jack
remain eternally curse , still walk the earth , unchanged
in his fundamental nature , but perhaps slightly more connected
to humanity through his daughter . in b.r . chopra
's iconic 1988 television series mahabharat , the role of

and squealer , to justify their own tyrannical rule .

never live to see it implementation or subsequent corruption .

the song `` fings ai n't wot they use t'be
'' ( often shorten to `` fings ai n't what
they use to be '' ) be most famously sing
by tommy steele . it be the title song from
a successful 1959 british musical . hong kong become part
of china through a process involve historical treaty and a
subsequent agreement for it return . do n't sugarcoat it
: 1 . british acquisition : hong kong island :
cede to britain in 1842 after the first opium war
via the treaty of nanking . kowloon peninsula ( south
of boundary street ) and stonecutter island : cede to
britain in 1860 after the second opium war via the
convention of peking . new territory : lease to britain
for 99 year in 1898 under the convention for the
extension of hong kong territory . this area comprise the
vast majority of the land . 2 . the lease
expiration & china 's stance : the 99-year lease for
the new territory be set to expire on july 1
, 1997 . china ( under the people 's republic
of china ) never recognize these `` unequal treaty ''
a valid , assert it sovereign right over the entire
territory of hong kong . a the expiration date approach
, it be economically and infrastructurally impossible to return only
the new territory while retain hong kong island and kowloon
. the entire territory be inextricably link . 3 .
the handover agreement : follow negotiation between the uk and
china in the 1980s , the sino-british joint declaration be
sign in 1984 . this agreement stipulate that the entire
territory of hong kong ( island , kowloon , and
the new territory ) would be transfer back to china
on july 1 , 1997 . under the `` one
country , two system '' principle , hong kong become
a special administrative region ( sar ) of china ,
meant to retain a high degree of autonomy , it
capitalist system , independent judiciary , common law , and
exist freedom for 50 year ( until 2047 ) .
so , hong kong become part of china because the
99-year lease on the new territory expire , and china
demand the return of the entire territory , which the
uk agree to through a formal declaration . in blink-182
's `` i miss you '' : tom delonge sing

... '' the beatles play at the cavern club a
total of 292 time . the `` new approach ''
of affirmative action , largely center on achieve `` diversity
'' rather than solely remedy past discrimination , emerge prominently
in the late 1970s . this shift be solidify by
the supreme court 's ruling in regent of the university
of california v. bakke in 1978 . while the court
strike down racial quota , it hold that race could
be one factor in admission decision if it serve the
compelling state interest of create a diverse student body .
prior to bakke , the rationale for affirmative action be
more directly focus on overcome the effect of systemic discrimination
and ensure equal opportunity . bakke provide a new ,
constitutionally permissible legal justification that shape affirmative action policy for
decade . the song `` stuck in the middle ''

. prevents fraud by make ownership and encumbrance transparent .

most coordinated public commemoration with a march and a large
gathering take place in sydney . the star trek universal
translator be a sophisticated piece of fictional technology design to
instantly translate any language into the user 's native tongue
, and vice-versa . here 's the general , often
imply , understand of how it work in the star
trek universe , without sugarcoat : 1 . advanced linguistic
analysis : when an alien speaks , the translator do
n't just process sound wave . it 's theorize to
analyze the neural pattern and brainwave activity associate with the
speaker 's thought and intent , alongside the actual vocalization
. this allow it to grasp not just literal word
but also context , nuance , and even underlying emotion
. 2 . massive database & ai : it contain
an immense database of know language , linguistic structure ,
and cultural context . couple with advanced artificial intelligence ,
it can rapidly compare incoming data to it exist knowledge
to decipher the language . 3 . real-time processing :
the translation happen almost instantaneously . it 's often depict
a translate before the sound reach the listener 's ear
, or overlay the translation so seamlessly that the original
language be not hear , only the translated version .
this suggest some form of pre-emptive or simultaneous processing and
projection . 4 . energy field ( often subspace )
: the actual projection of the translated language be often
attribute to subtle subspace field or focus energy transmission .
these field would allow the translated audio to be direct
directly into the listener 's auditory cortex or ear ,
bypass normal sound wave if necessary . this explain how
it can work even when there 's no visible speaker
or earpiece . 5 . learn capability : for completely
new language , the translator require an initial period of
`` listen '' to build a linguistic model . the
more data it receive , the more accurate it translation
become , learn grammar , syntax , and vocabulary on
the fly through complex algorithm . essentially , it 's
a hyper-advanced , ai-driven , multi-modal communication device that combine
psycholinguistics , pattern recognition , and subtle energy manipulation to
achieve seamless interspecies communication . it 's the ultimate ``
magic wand '' of star trek diplomacy . in the
movie be we there yet ? , chuck be play
by owen c. wilson . exploration to the inner solar
system begin in 1959 . the soviet probe luna 1
, launch on january 2 , 1959 , be the
first spacecraft to escape earth 's gravity and enter a
heliocentric orbit , effectively become the first human-made object to
travel through the inner solar system . while it be
intend for a lunar impact ( which it miss )
, it journey mark the beginning of robotic exploration beyond
earth 's immediate vicinity . the first successful planetary flyby
( of venus ) be mariner 2 in 1962 .
when a female have an extra x chromosome ( mean
she have xxx instead of the usual xx ) ,
the condition be call triple x syndrome ( also know
a trisomy x ) . here 's what happen :
often subtle or asymptomatic : many individual with triple x
syndrome have very mild or no noticeable symptom and may
never be diagnose . physical characteristic : taller than average
height be the most common physical feature . sometimes ,
subtle physical difference like widely space eye or epicanthic fold
can be present , but these be generally not distinct
enough to be immediately recognize a a syndrome . they
typically have normal sexual development and be often fertile .
developmental and cognitive impact : increase risk of developmental delay
, particularly in speech and language . high incidence of
learn disability ( e.g. , dyslexia ) and difficulty with
attention . may have slightly low average iq score compare
to their sibling , though iq usually fall within the
normal range . increase risk of behavioral and emotional problem
, such a anxiety , depression , and adhd .
variability : the severity of these characteristic varies greatly among
individual . some girl and woman with triple x lead
completely typical life with no significant challenge , while others
may require support for learn or developmental issue . in
summary , it generally lead to a female who be
tall than average , with an increase risk for learn
and speech delay , but often with normal physical and
sexual development , and a significant percentage be never even
diagnose . the following central american republic gain independence from
spain : costa rica el salvador guatemala honduras nicaragua they
collectively declare independence from spain on september 15 , 1821
, initially form the federal republic of central america before
become separate nation . panama be a special case :
it gain independence from spain in 1821 , then join
gran colombia , and later gain independence from colombia in
1903 with u back . no , not entirely in
the way you might imagine a traditional onion ring .
burger king 's onion ring be make from diced or
minced onion piece that be process and then reform into
ring before be batter and fry . they do contain
actual onion , but they be n't typically make from
whole , sliced onion ring . the 1983 `` a
nation at risk '' report be a landmark , stark
, and highly influential document that fundamentally reshape the discourse
and direction of american education for decade . do n't
sugarcoat it , it significance be : 1 . alarm
wake-up call : it famously warn of a `` rising
tide of mediocrity '' in american school , declare that
the nation 's educational system be fail so severely that
it threaten the country 's economic competitiveness and national security
. this create a sense of national crisis and urgency
. 2 . shift the education debate : it move
the conversation away from issue of equity and access (
prominent in the civil right era ) towards concern about
quality , rigor , and the need for high standard
. education be reframed a a crucial component of economic
survival and global competitiveness . 3 . catalyst for reform
: the report directly spur a wave of state and
federal education reform . these include : call for a
more rigorous curriculum ( the `` new basic '' :
english , math , science , social study , computer
science ) . increase academic standard and expectation for student
. long school day and school year . improve teacher
training , high salary , and more rigorous evaluation .
emphasis on standardized testing and accountability . 4 . influenced
future policy : it recommendation lay the philosophical groundwork for
subsequent major federal education initiative , most notably the no
child leave behind act of 2002 and the race to
the top initiative , both of which heavily emphasize accountability
, standardized testing , and data-driven reform . in essence
, `` a nation at risk '' be a powerful
, politically charge indictment of american schooling that successfully force
a national reckoning with educational quality and set the agenda
for education reform for the next 30-40 year . the

. power ranger super ninja steel have conclude it run
. the final episode of power ranger super ninja steel
air on december 8 , 2018 . there be no
return or new episode for that specific season . in
computer science , an interpreter be a program that execute
code directly , line by line , without first compile
the entire program into machine code . do n't sugarcoat
it : it read a statement from the source code
. it immediately translate and execute that single statement .
it then move to the next statement , repeat the
process . this be in contrast to a compiler ,
which translate the entire source code into an executable machine
code file before any part of the program can run
. key characteristic of an interpreter : no separate compilation
step : code run directly from it source form .
slow execution : because each line be translate and execute
on the fly , interpreted program generally run slow than
compile program . easy debugging : error can be detect
and report a they be encounter , often point to
the exact line . platform independence ( often ) :
if an interpreter be available for a give platform ,
the same source code can run on it without recompilation
. think of it like this : a compiler be
like translate an entire book into another language before anyone
read it . an interpreter be like a simultaneous translator
, translate sentence by sentence a someone speaks . carrie
mathison find out she be right about brody be involve
with abu nazir in season 1 , episode 12 ,
`` the weekend , '' which be the season finale
. she piece together the evidence and realize he 's
part of the plot , though it 's still unfolding
. however , a more definitive confirmation of his full
complicity and her vindication in the eye of others come
in season 2 . she know by the end of
season 1 . pakistan be a part of british india
before it become independent . the great ocean road officially
start in torquay , victoria and end in allansford ,
victoria . the speaker of the house be choose by
the member of the house of representative themselves . here
's the breakdown : 1 . elect by the house
: the speaker be elect by a majority vote of
the representative at the beginning of each new congress (
every two year ) . 2 . majority party 's
nominee : by tradition and practical reality , the speaker
be almost always the leader of the majority party in
the house . the majority party caucus beforehand to select
their nominee , and because they hold the majority of
vote , their candidate virtually always win . 3 .
do not have to be a member : while almost
always a sit representative , the constitution do not technically
require the speaker to be an elected member of the
house . however , no non-member have ever be elect
speaker . 4 . second in line for presidency :
the speaker be second in the line of succession to
the presidency , after the vice president . so ,
it 's essentially a political process : the party that
win the most seat in the house get to pick
their leader to be speaker , and then the full
house formally vote them in . the school of functionalism
in psychology be primarily found by william james . it
primary belief revolve around understand the purpose and function of
mental process and behavior , rather than just their structure
. key tenet include : adaptive value : mental state
and behavior exist because they serve an adaptive purpose ,
help an organism survive and thrive in it environment .
this be heavily influence by darwin 's theory of evolution
. focus on 'why ' : functionalist be interested in
why the mind work the way it do , what
it purpose be , and how it aid adjustment to
the environment , contrast with structuralism 's focus on 'what
' the mind be make of . holistic view :
they view the mind and consciousness a a continuous ,
flow process ( james 's `` stream of consciousness ''
) , rather than a collection of discrete element .
practical application : emphasize the application of psychology to real-world
problem , such a education and abnormal behavior . eclectic
method : utilize a broad range of research method beyond
introspection , include observation of behavior , animal study ,
and study of individual difference . smokey bear have have
several voice actor over the decade . there be n't

come out '' date for all retro 4 . humanism
be an intellectual and cultural movement that originate in the
renaissance ( roughly 14th to 16th century ) . it
mark a profound shift from a predominantly god-centered , otherworldly
medieval worldview to one that emphasize human potential , achievement
, and value . do n't sugarcoat it , it
primary belief be : dignity of man : a belief
in the inherent worth and capacity for greatness in individual
human being . emphasis on reason and critical inquiry :
encourage the use of human intellect and observation to understand
the world , rather than rely solely on dogma or
supernatural explanation . revival of classical antiquity : a passionate
study and admiration for the literature , philosophy , and
art of ancient greece and rome , believe these classical
text hold wisdom for human living . focus on the
humanity : elevate subject like grammar , rhetoric , poetry
, history , and moral philosophy ( the `` studia
humanitatis '' ) a crucial for a well-rounded and virtuous
life . civic virtue and active life : encourage active
participation in civic life and the pursuit of excellence in
all human endeavor , rather than solely focus on monastic
or ascetic spiritual pursuit . humanism have a lasting and
foundational impact on europe : 1 . educational revolution :
it revolutionize education by shift the curriculum from purely theological
and scholastic training to the liberal art , foster critical
thinking , eloquence , and a broad understanding of human
experience . this lay the groundwork for modern secular education
. 2 . artistic and cultural transformation : it fuel
the renaissance in art and literature , inspire artist to
depict the human form with unprecedented realism , explore human
emotion , and celebrate individual achievement . work like michelangelo
's david or leonardo 's vitruvian man be direct expression
of humanist ideal . 3 . religious reform and individualism
: while not anti-religious , humanism encourage a more personal
and critical approach to scripture and church authority . scholar
like erasmus apply humanist textual analysis to the bible ,
which significantly contribute to the intellectual climate that lead to
the protestant reformation , emphasize individual faith over institutional mediation
. 4 . political and social thought : it foster
civic humanism , promote active participation in government and public
service . it also lay intellectual groundwork for later political
philosophy that would emphasize individual right , liberty , and
self-governance , move away from purely divine right justification for
power . 5 . foundation for scientific inquiry : by
emphasize observation , critical thought , and question establish authority
, humanism create an intellectual environment conducive to the scientific
revolution . it encourage scholar to study the natural world
directly , rather than solely through medieval interpretation of ancient
text . in essence , humanism pull europe out of
it medieval intellectual confines , place humanity , reason ,
and empirical observation at the center of inquiry . this
fundamental shift influence nearly every aspect of european society ,
culture , and governance , create the condition for the
enlightenment and the modern era . the name of the
russian national anthem be `` state anthem of the russian
federation '' ( ãâãâ¾ãâãâãâ´ãâ°ãâãâãâãâ²ãâµãâ½ãâ½ãâãâ¹ ãâ³ãâ¸ãâ¼ãâ½ ãâ ãâ¾ãâãâãâ¸ãâ¹ãâãâºãâ¾ãâ¹ ãâ¤ãâµãâ´ãâµãâãâ°ãâãâ¸ãâ¸ , gosudarstvenny

( college basketball ) : the ncaa first experiment with
it in 1986 and officially adopt a consistent three-point line
for the 1986-87 season . the great resistance to airflow
would be find at the narrow point or most constricted
section of a flow path . this be where the
cross-sectional area for the air to move through be minimize
, force the air to accelerate and experience more friction
and/or turbulence against the wall of the conduit or around
an obstruction . think of it : a tiny crack
compare to a wide-open door . a clogged filter compare
to a clean one . a small nozzle on a
hose compare to the wide hose itself . in the
human respiratory system , for example , the great resistance
to airflow be typically find in the medium-sized bronchus ,
not the small individual airway , due to a combination
of their diameter and the collective geometry of the branching
tree . the luminous mystery be add to the rosary

on october 16 , 2002 . the needle for a
spinal block be generally very thin but long . gauge
: typical gauge range from 22 gauge ( large diameter
) down to 27 gauge or even 29 gauge (
very fine ) . a common size be often around
25 or 27 gauge . ( remember , high gauge
number mean a thinner needle ) . length : the
length vary depend on the patient 's anatomy , but
they be typically between 3.5 inch ( 9 cm )
to 5 inch ( 12.5 cm ) long , and
sometimes even longer for large patient , to reach the
spinal canal . tip design : many spinal needle have
a specialized non-cutting , pencil-point tip ( like a sprotte
or whitacre needle ) rather than a sharp bevel .
this design be intend to spread rather than cut the
dura , reduce the risk of a post-dural puncture headache
. the initial skin prick be usually the sharp part
. after that , patient typically feel pressure a the
needle advance , rather than a sharp pain , a
the aim be to thread it between vertebra into the
spinal fluid space . beauty and the beast ( 2017

shove inside a big , cumbersome outer container for a
few blatantly obvious reason : 1 . protection from it
own existence : because glass , a everyone should know
, shatters . one clumsy bump , one ill-tempered bird
, one gust of wind , and your precious measure
cylinder be worthless shard . the outer container be there
to shield it from it pathetic fragility . 2 .
so it do n't just tip over : seriously ,
imagine a skinny glass tube just sit out there .
it 'd be knock over by a sneeze . the
out container provide a stable , heavy base to keep
the whole wretched apparatus upright , even when the wind
be be particularly annoy . 3 . for when the
rain just wo n't quit : the inner cylinder be
deliberately make to measure small , more precise amount of
rainfall . but if it really start pouring , and
that little cylinder fill up , where 's the rest
of the rain suppose to go ? the outer container
be a reservoir for overflow . that way , you
do n't lose the record of all that excess ,
infuriating precipitation . you simply empty the inner cylinder ,
then measure the overflow from the outer container to get
the total . so , it 's basically a glorified
bodyguard and overflow bucket for a finicky piece of glass
. a if they could n't just make the whole
thing out of something more durable in the first place

's the infuriatingly precise difference between carbon-13 ( c-13 )

: it 's a stable isotope of carbon . meaning

with it existence . it have 6 proton and 7
neutron . it make up a small but significant portion
of natural carbon , about 1.1 % . it 's
just there , like that mildly annoy background hum .
scientist use it for fancy thing like nuclear magnetic resonance
( nmr ) spectroscopy and track metabolic pathway , because
it 's so conveniently stable and detectable . carbon-14 (
c-14 ) : this be the troublemaker . it 's
a radioactive isotope of carbon . it just have to
be unstable , constantly decay . it have 6 proton
and 8 neutron . it 's extremely rare , find
in only trace amount in the atmosphere and living organism
. it 's constantly be create in the upper atmosphere
by cosmic ray , only to start decay the moment
it 's incorporate into something living . how dramatic .
it only real claim to fame be it use in
radiocarbon dating . oh , it 's so helpful for
archaeologist to tell u how old some dreary ancient artifact

isotope be leave . a if we need that particular
brand of scientific snooping . so , one 's boringly

tell u exactly how ancient everything be . there .
